author: jrydval
body:
# Steps to reproduce

insert formatted USB flash media into MacOS based machine
+
submit `Get-PSDrive` command


# Expected behavior

It should display also USB drive. At least based on the help text for `Get-PSDrive`:

> Also, beginning in Windows PowerShell 3.0, when an external drive is connected to the computer, PowerShell automatically adds a PSDrive to the file system that
>     represents the new drive. You do not need to restart PowerShell. Similarly, when an external drive is disconnected from the computer, PowerShell automatically
>     deletes the PSDrive that represents the removed drive.

`mount` sees it (see last line):

```
PS /Users/jan> mount
/dev/disk1s5 on / (apfs, local, read-only, journaled)
devfs on /dev (devfs, local, nobrowse)
/dev/disk1s1 on /System/Volumes/Data (apfs, local, journaled, nobrowse)
/dev/disk1s4 on /private/var/vm (apfs, local, journaled, nobrowse)
map auto_home on /System/Volumes/Data/home (autofs, automounted, nobrowse)
/dev/disk2s1 on /Volumes/Pulec (exfat, local, nodev, nosuid, noowners)

```

# Actual behavior

USB drive is not displayed:

```

PS /Users/jan> Get-PSDrive

Name           Used (GB)     Free (GB) Provider      Root                                                                                                 CurrentLocation
----           ---------     --------- --------      ----                                                                                                 ---------------
/                 155.46         78.01 FileSystem    /                                                                                                          Users/jan
Alias                                  Alias
Env                                    Environment
Function                               Function
Temp              155.46         78.01 FileSystem    /tmp/
Variable                               Variable

```

# Environment data

```
PS /Users/jan> $PSVersionTable

Name                           Value
----                           -----
PSVersion                      7.0.0-rc.1
PSEdition                      Core
GitCommitId                    7.0.0-rc.1
OS                             Darwin 19.2.0 Darwin Kernel Version 19.2.0: Sat Nov  9 03:47:04 PST 2019; root:xnu-6153.61.1~20/RELEASE_X86_64
Platform                       Unix
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0…}
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1
WSManStackVersion              3.0

```

comments.author: jhoneill
comments.body: On non windows machines what drive would you expect a USB stick to be. On Windows you have C: D: E:  But (showing my windows-centricity here) you don't get a new drive letter  / filesystem, the usb mounts into the existing / file system . So it is left to you to create and name a drive pointing somewhere in the existing FS.

comments.author: jrydval
comments.body:
Hm, I would expect that it shows precisely the same (from conceptual point of view) as on Windows - a path to the drive - in my case on Mac /Volume/Pulec on Windows E:\\
Then I can use it for  `Set-Location` to be there.

comments.author: jhoneill
comments.body:
A drive name can't contain   ; ~ / \ . : 
So you couldn't have a drive named /volume/Pulec. 
On Windows you have have multiple file systems which don't (by default) mount into one unifying one (hence they begin with A: B: C:  etc.). PowerShell doesn't _create_ a drive named "E", it recognizes "E" as a system drive.  If you connect Z: to \\localhost\c$  outside PowerShell, it shows up as a PS drive. PS Drives is Aliases + Environment + Functions + Variables + filesystems known to the OS +  Windows' Registry + Certificates + WSMAN
On Unix-derived OSes there is one unified fs in which other file systems mount. Because there isn't a new file system root there is no drive to add. You can make a Windows style drive (so in WSL I can create a PS drive 'C' for /mnt/c ) or one can make a short name for a mounted USB.  But there wouldn't be much point in in creating a psdrive Volume_Pulec in order to allow `set-Location volume_pulec: ` instead of `set-Location /volume/pulec `

comments.author: jhoneill
comments.body:
@scaleoutsean 

That's expected behaviour.  The Term "Drive" is inherited from  windows as analogous to "root-of-a-[pseudo]-file-system" 
Your filesystems on those disks are mounted into part of the / "drive",  they aren't roots in their own right as they would normally be on Windows.     

You **can** create new drives for places in the /  tree   for example
`New-PSDrive -Name C -PSProvider FileSystem -Root /mnt/c`  
Would present a C: drive on pwsh if that is a more convenient way to work.  But that is in addition to where the OS places them - on Linux system you'd expect to find them mounted somewhere under / wouldn't you ? And native Linux tools would probably demand you use the path from / not a C: style one.
